Title: Computability Theory (ii): uncomputable numbers.
Description: During my current incursion in computability theory I learnt about uncomputable numbers, this is, numbers that can’t be computed with arbitrary precision. This means that even given all the computational power in the universe you could not compute these numbers. Even if God himself came from Heaven, he could not compute these numbers. Uncomputable numbers are numbers that can’t be computed because of maths limitations. Just the idea that maths has some inherent limits amazed me. In my last post, I talked about the halting problem, which is a limitation of maths, but the halting problem is a little bit abstract in my opinion. In this post, instead, I’ll show that there are numbers for which we can know an approximate value but can’t be known with arbitrary precision.

Title: Computability Theory (i): the Halting Problem.
Description: During these last few days I’ve been reading a little bit about computability theory, and I feel like a kid with a new toy, so I’m going to write some posts about this topic. I don’t pretend to explain anything new, and probably what I’m going to write has been written before, but I’ll write these posts for two reasons: (1) as future notes for myself, and (2) to help me clarify and organize the ideas.

Title: NET Data Community Standup: New EF Core 7.0 APIs (Bulk Update)
Description:
EF Core 7.0 introduces the ExecuteUpdate and ExecuteDelete APIs, which allow you to easily use LINQ to express a database update or delete operation. These APIs can be far more efficient for applying changes to multiple rows based on a condition, e.g. “delete rows which have InActive set to true” (AKA bulk update scenarios). But in some scenarios, they also allow you to express changes over a single row in a much more succinct and simple way, simplifying your code. ExecuteUpdate and ExecuteDelete completely bypass EF’s change tracking and execute immediately, as opposed to when SaveChanges is called. Tune in to learn more and to explore the new possibilities that these new APIs bring!

Featuring: Arthur Vickers (@ajcvickers), Shay Rojansky (@shayrojansky)

Title: LiteDB - A .NET embedded NoSQL database
Description:
In this article we will have a closer look at LiteDB, a .NET NoSQL Document Store in a single data file. We will discover the advantages of LiteDB and why it is a viable candidate for your next project.
We will also explore what are the differences between a NoSQL and a classical SQL database are and what this has to do with the reminiscent SQL CE or the more modern SQLite database.

Title: JavaScript metaprogramming with the 2022-03 decorators API
Description: JavaScript decorators have finally reached stage 3! Their latest version is already supported by Babel and will soon be supported by TypeScript. This blog post covers the 2022-03 version (stage 3) of the ECMAScript proposal “Decorators” by Daniel Ehrenberg and Chris Garrett. In principle, decorators are a JavaScript feature for library authors: They let them define @-prefixed keywords that can be put in front of classes and various class members (such as methods) and change how these constructs work – for example: @freeze class C {} The decorator @freeze changes class C so that all of its instances are frozen. We’ll implement this decorator later. Users of libraries profit indirectly from decorators because they get features that are based on them. Decorators are mostly an object-oriented feature and popular in OOP frameworks and libraries such as Ember, Angular, Vue, web component frameworks and MobX. In this blog post, we learn how decorators work and use our knowledge to implement several of them.
